fields.description:

{code}
final FileRevisionKeyData fileData = new FileRevisionKeyData(path, revision);
StreamingOutput output = new StreamingOutput() {
  public void write(OutputStream output) throws IOException, WebApplicationException {
    contentService.getContent(fishEyeRepo, fileData, output);
  }
};
{code}

fields.description:
It would be nice if FE sent e-mail notifications to a specified group of users, everytime a repository reindex (i.e. a full reindex) has started/completed/aborted?

Usecases are:

    * The repository`s admin should be informed about the uncommon serverload. (Otherwise he would start to investigate why there is an uncommon server load)
    * The FeCru admin wants to get informed when a reindex has been stopped due to errors
    * FeCru users want to know when they can use a repository (i.e. when the reindex has completed)
fields.summary: E-Mail notification for reindex status

fields.description:
A NullPointerException occurs when FishEye asks for the manifest at a revision and cannot resolve one of the files to a revision in the repository index:

{noformat}
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.hg.HgCache$2.visit(HgCache.java:220)
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.hg.HgCache$2.visit(HgCache.java:217)
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.hg.client.HgClientManifestDAO$1.doProcessLine(HgClientManifestDAO.java:66)
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.dvcs.handler.DvcsLineOutputHandler.processLine(DvcsLineOutputHandler.java:23)
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.LineOutputHandler.process(LineOutputHandler.java:49)
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.LineOutputHandler.process(LineOutputHandler.java:36)
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.PluggableProcessHandler.processOutput(PluggableProcessHandler.java:34)
	at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcess$4.doTask(ExternalProcess.java:265)
	... 4 more
{noformat}

FishEye is asking hg for the manifest for the repository at some revision (the list of files that exist at that revision). It gets a list of path+version entries from hg and tries to resolve each of those to a file revision in the InfinityDb database.

It is failing to resolve one of those entries and gets null as a result. Later on, the code tries to get an attribute from the null filerevision resulting in the NPE.

At this point the filerevision should not be null, so this is probably a symptom of an underlying issue.
fields.summary: NPE during Mercurial indexing

fields.description:
It is possible to set set an invalid license on FishEye using the DefaultFisheyeAccessor.setLicense method. This method should perform validation on the incoming string and reject it if it is an invalid license.

I'm not 100% sure what should happen for expired licenses, but I reckon they should be allowed for testing purposes.
fields.summary: DefaultFisheyeAccessor sets the license before validating it

fields.description:
The indexing of a ClearCase repository stops in error with the following error message:

{noformat}
Repository index failed due to error com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryClientException: com.atlassian.fisheye.clearcase.ClearCaseProcessException: 
Error executing command (desc -fmt "%[component]Xp d:%[depends_on_closure]Xp" some_baseline_name@/path/to/pvob ) : : 
cleartool: Error: Unable to access "some_baseline_name@/path/to/pvob": No such file or directory. 
com.atlassian.fisheye.clearcase.ClearCaseProcessException: 
Error executing command (desc -fmt "%[component]Xp d:%[depends_on_closure]Xp" some_baseline_name@/path/to/pvob ) : : 
cleartool: Error: Unable to access "some_baseline_name@/path/to/pvob": No such file or directory. 
com.atlassian.utils.process.ProcessException: 
cleartool: Error: Unable to access "some_baseline_name@/path/to/pvob": No such file or directory.
{noformat}

This error indicates that the {{baseline:}} prefix is missing from the {{some_baseline_name@/path/to/pvob}} argument.

It appears that in some cases cleartool doesn't return the extended name of baselines.  The fix is to add the {{baseline:}} prefix if it isn't returned by cleartool
fields.summary: UCM ClearCase: indexing error 'No such file or directory'

fields.description:
If the repository has empty directories (grey in the source tree), the repositories will be shown in the Branch list in reports.

Steps to reproduce:
# Create and delete a directory under /PRJ/branches
# The directory will be grey in the Source tree for the project
# Go to Reports tab
# click the gear in the left

What happens: the deleted directories are shown in the list

Expected behavior: they shouldn't appear or it should be configurable.
fields.summary: Report filter is showing wrong Branches in 'Branch' list

fields.description:
The logs fill up with errors similar to:
{quote}
10:49:20 ERROR - Attempting to insert a revision which already exists for tags/1.0/tags/0.10/path/to/file.txt
{quote}
usually experienced with bad svn branch/tag structure. 
In one particular case it happened due to self-referencing "svn add" operations.

More details are on [this|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHKB/ERROR+-+Attempting+to+Insert+a+Revison+which+Already+Exists] KB.

It would be helpful to handle this problem better with more descriptive error reporting instead of filling up the logs repeatedly with the above error.
fields.summary: Better error handling for "Attempting to insert a revison which already exists"

fields.description:
FishEye's maintenance manager currently supports passing in a runnable, that puts FishEye in maintenance mode, executes the runnable, and then takes FishEye out of maintenance mode in a finally block.

JIRA Studio, when it detects a fatal error in its initial data setup that requires a support engineer to diagnose and fix the problem before anything else happens, needs a mechanism for putting FishEye into maintenance mode indefinitely.  The process in Studio will be something like this:

# Studio detects a fatal error
# A trouble ticket is automatically raised on SAC
# FishEye is put into maintenance mode, notifying the customer that a support issue has been raised
# A Studio engineer diagnoses and fixes the problem, and restarts FishEye, which will take it out of maintenance mode
fields.summary: Provide a mechanism to put FishEye in maintenance mode indefinitely

fields.description:
Currently can group by:
* csid (csid, comment, date, author, aggregates)
* file (path, aggregates)
* dir (dir, aggregates)

I propose that a new level be added for "reviews"
* review (review, aggregates)

I'd really like to generate a report that shows all distinct reviews for a SCM date range on a repository.

where {where clause to select revisions}
group by review
return review, count(distinct csid), count(distinct path), count(distinct author)
fields.summary: Add EyeQL group by review

fields.description:
Using java 64 bit server VM 1.6.0_18.

I am getting the following messages when trying to index a particular SVN repository for the first time. Unfortunately I can't paste the stack trace from the log but here are the main messages:

fields.description:
Fisheye currently holds a lot of file handles open, and this seems to have gotten worse in recent releases.

The baseline seems to be around 500 handles for jars, plus 30 per non-passivated repository (up to 100), and then normal transient things consume more on top of this.  Lucene indexes are the main issue here, particularly when the merge procedure breaks down and more than 10 files per index are kept.  We suspect that because merging indexes can require a lot of file handles once we start running low the indexes have more trouble merging, which accelerates the process of running out of handles.

The workaround for linux system experiencing the "Too Many Open Files" error is described [in this knowledge base article|http://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=137265407].
fields.summary: Reduce the number of open file handles used by fisheye

fields.description:
In ClearCase, versions of a file can be deleted from a VOB. This completely removes the version from the VOB and its content or info about the version can no longer be retrieved from ClearCase. 

If FishEye has already indexed the version, the version is still displayed in the UI and FishEye will attempt to retrieve the content using cleartool. This will fail with the following error:

{noformat}
fisheye.app com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.BaseRepositoryScanner-handleSlurpException - Problem processing revisions from repo some-repo due to class 
com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.DbException - com.atlassian.fisheye.clearcase.ClearCaseProcessException: Error executing command (cleartool get -to 
/home/fe-user/fisheye_data/var/tmp/699a3eaf.391611e0.8568.00014268d9285526839728504363906.tmp path/to/deleted/file@@/main/branch/2 ) : cleartool: 
Error: "path/to/deleted/file@@/main/branch/2" does not exist, or is not a ClearCase version, or is a checked out version which was removed.
 : Non-zero exit code: 1
{noformat}

The same error can also occur during content indexing if the version is seen during initial/incremental indexing, but is deleted before content indexing begins. In that case the repository in question will stop indexing and display an indexing error. 

Currently, the only way to recover is to do either exclude the file using exclude rules in the repository config (in administration), or do a full re-index of the repository.

FishEye should handle this more gracefully.

At a minimum:
* Indexing should not fail if a 'history rewrite' is encountered.
* Getting the content of the file in the UI should not generate an error.

Ideally:
* The file revision is question is also removed (or marked as removed) from the FishEye index.
* The ancestry (parent and child revisions) of the file revision's descendants are updated to no longer point to the deleted revision.
fields.summary: ClearCase: FishEye doesn't handle versions that are deleted from a ClearCase VOB

fields.description: Whenever a new file is added to the repository a new revision will be created and fisheye will send notification mail to the watchers.If svn:Add:need-lock property is enabled in the repository,SVN will create a new revision for enabling svn:needs-lock property.Fisheye will send notification to watchers for each new revision. Can we avoid this. We don't want an email for any commit done by svn:Add:need-lock property
fields.summary: FishEye Notification for SVN

fields.description:
There are a number of situations in which cleartool exits with an error code that FishEye doesn't consider to be errors:

* cleartool lsview <viewname> for a viewname that does not exist
* cleartool lshistory -branch <branch-name> vob/component-path for a branch that has no versions in the vob/component-path

FishEye deals with this by inspecting the error message returned by cleartool and handling 'expected' error messages.

However, sometimes FishEye doesn't receive the error message from cleartool and can't handle the error gracefully. As a result indexing stops with an indexing error, for instance:

{noformat}
2011-02-22 13:02:16,647 ERROR [IncrementalPinger2 some-repo] fisheye.app BaseRepositoryScanner-handleSlurpException - Problem processing 
revisions from repo TestAutomation_14.0 due to class com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryClientException - com.atlassian.fisheye.clearcase.ClearCaseProcessException: 
Error executing command (lshistory -all -since 31-December-1969.19:00:00 -branch some-branch -fmt "%Nd %[activity]p\n" vob/somevob ) :  : 
com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryClientException: com.atlassian.fisheye.clearcase.ClearCaseProcessException: Error executing command 
(lshistory -all -since 31-December-1969.19:00:00 -branch some-branch -fmt "%Nd %[activity]p\n" vob/somevob ) :  : 
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.clearcase.ClearCaseRepositoryScanner.processRevisions(ClearCaseRepositoryScanner.java:559)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.BaseRepositoryScanner.slurpRepository(BaseRepositoryScanner.java:291)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.BaseRepositoryScanner.doSlurpTransaction(BaseRepositoryScanner.java:258)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.BaseRepositoryScanner.ping(BaseRepositoryScanner.java:190)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.BaseRepositoryEngine.doSlurp(BaseRepositoryEngine.java:85)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryEngine.slurp(RepositoryEngine.java:387)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.ping.OneOffPingRequest.doRequest(OneOffPingRequest.java:25)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.ping.PingRequest.process(PingRequest.java:66)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryHandle.processPingRequests(RepositoryHandle.java:132)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryHandle.queuePingRequest(RepositoryHandle.java:122)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.ping.PingRequest.run(PingRequest.java:33)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1110)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:603)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:636)
Caused by: com.atlassian.fisheye.clearcase.ClearCaseProcessException: Error executing command (lshistory -all -since 31-December-1969.19:00:00 
-branch some-branch -fmt "%Nd %[activity]p\n" vob/somevob ) : *<missing error message>* : 
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.clearcase.ClearCaseContext.runInteractiveProcess(ClearCaseContext.java:304)
{noformat}

These errors are intermittent; as far as we've seen the same command succeeds (that is, FishEye will intercept and handle the cleartool error) on the next indexing run.  

We need to investigate whether we can handle this more gracefully. One option is to use the exit code of the cleartool process to identify the error condition, assuming that the exit code uniquely identifies the error conditions.

Another strategy is to avoid the error conditions by changing the cleartool commands that FishEye is using. Most of the issues we've seen are triggered by the lshistory command. An option is to move from per-branch processing to per-vob/component processing and filter the output for the branches we're interested in. However, this will result in much more cleartool output and potentially decreased indexing performance.
fields.summary: ClearCase: cleartool error message is missed by FishEye and as a result indexing stops in error for known 'error' conditions

fields.description:
When creating a Project and Permission Scheme in Crucible / Fisheye there is no way to hide the People / Users or at least limit it so that only people are visible if they are in the same project or have access to the same repository.

For example:
Users A, B & C are in Project 1, when clicking on the People tab they should only see Users A, B & C.  Instead the people tab displays Users A, B, C .... N.

fields.description:
Reported in support case [FSH-5132|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/FSH-5132], reproduced in the attached repository.

* If you delete a sub-directory of a tag, the changeset is not indexed, the tag annotation is removed from the associated file revision of that subdirectory and no tag: branch is created (all good except for the lack of changeset)
* If you delete an entire tag directory, the changeset is indexed, the tag annotation is removed from the associated file revisions and no tag: branch is created (all good)
* If you add an extra directory as part of the tag creation, then subsequently delete that extra directory, the changeset is indexed, and a tag: branch is created (kind of strange, but probably a rare edge case)
fields.summary: In svn, a changeset which deletes a subdirectory of a tag directory isn't counted as a changeset by fisheye and doesn't appear in the activity stream

fields.description:
Handling of files designated as unicode on a unicode enabled server may fail to be correctly parsed.

This leads to problems in diffs, line counts and annotations. The problems may manifest in the following ways
# Diffs do not show all line changes
# Linecounts are inaccurate
# Annotations do not show all lines and may cause the server to report an error.

There is no workaround.
fields.summary: P4 Unicode Handling

fields.description:
I want to add extra information to annotated views of files, and to diffs using a [Gutter Renderer Module|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FECRUDEV/Gutter+Renderer+Plugin+Tutorial].

It seems that the DiffLineDecorator works but not the LineDecorator: method {{LineDecorator.decorateLine(int i)}} is never call. 

h5. Details
I've created the {{GutterRenderer}}, the {{DiffLineDecorator}} and the {{LineDecorator}}.

* When I go on a diff page:
** {{GutterRenderer.getAnnotationDecorators(DiffType diffType, String repository, String fromPath, String fromRev, String toPath, String toRev)}} is called, a single element list of {{DiffLineDecorator}} is returned
** {{DiffLineDecorator.decorateLineXXX(...)}} is called
** The gutter is visible with the html specified in {{decorateLineXXX}} methods.
 
* When I go on an annotated file:
** {{getAnnotationDecorators(String repository, String path, String rev)}} is called, a single element list of {{LineDecorator}} is returned
** {{LineDecorator.decorateLine(...)}} is never call
** The gutter is not present on the file
fields.summary: LineDecorator.decorateLine(int) never call

fields.description:
The branch selector does not show branches that don't have actual changes to files (doesn't affect SVN).

E.g. If a branch is created and committed in git/hg without changing any files, it does not show up.
fields.summary: Branch Selector only lists branches that have unique file changes

fields.description:
Git supports two types of tags: lightweight tags and tag objects. FishEye currently only indexes lightweight tags.

A lightweight tag is represented internally by git as follows:
  tag --> commit-object

A tag object on the other hand looks like this:
  tag --> tag-object --> some-other-object

Usually, a tag object points to a commit-object, but this need not be the case.

When using tag objects, FishEye will detect the the tag, but assumes that the thing the tag is pointing to (the tag object) is a commit. For tag objects this in not the case and a warning will be logged when DEBUG logging is turned on:

bq. Tag <tag-name> points to <hash>, which has not been indexed. Is the commit reachable from the current branch heads? Skipping tag.

(see http://book.git-scm.com/3_git_tag.html for an explanation).
fields.summary: FishEye does not support git tag objects

fields.description:
Don't think you can do this as of now, but if so please point me in the right direction, anyways here goes.

Whenever Code Metrics are shown in Fisheye they include all file types, as well as all directories.

h4. Directory Filters

Im not sure if the "Subversion Repository Structure" configuration can help me out on the directory part, but in my SVN repositories, I have the following structure for each project:

* \{projectName}/trunk/3rd - Third Party assemblies and related files
* \{projectName}/trunk/\{sub-dir-1}
* \{projectName}/trunk/\{sub-dir-2}

And so on, so currently when I view the "LOC" diagrams, it inclues the "3rd party folder" that I have, and when the "documentation xml" files is included (.Net projects), that sometimes really sum up in addition to License files etc.

So it would be desirable to exclude that from the metrics, yet I still wan't it in the "repository" browser since it is an important folder in terms of downloading tar balls and looking at changes.

h4. File Filters

Adding the ability to exclude files from the diagrams, there is as an example many files in .NET project structures that is not interesting when looking at the LOC, e.g. csproj, sln, designer.cs etc... since this is not developer written files, further in some cases I would like to just be able to view the .cs files.

It would be extra neat if this was a dynamic feature on the diagram pages, where one could enter an advanced filter
 - Regex: ".\*\.(cs|xml|config)" (unless ^ and/or $ is included, automatically add ^.\* and .\*$ to the start and end respectively).

Or in simple cases choose a file type from a drop down populated with maybe all or most common types.

Just as above these files are interesting when browsing the directories, but not much when viewing Metrics.
fields.summary: Filter for Code Metrics.

fields.description:
It seems as though we use the current date and time to choose which changesets to include in a watch email -- perhaps we could include commits after the current date & time too?

This may affect all repo types, but has been observed on git.
fields.summary: Clock skew between the machines hosting a git repository and FishEye may cause the wrong commits to appear in watch emails

fields.description:
FishEye currently ignores symbolic links in ClearCase repositories. They will not show up in the file tree or the activity log.

It would be helpful if FishEye would at least show the symbolic link in the file tree, possibly using a special 'symbolic link' icon. The 'source' view of the symbolic link could show the path the link is pointing to.
fields.summary: ClearCase: add support for symbolic links

fields.description:
In the "Repositories" section of the Fisheye admin-view the time of the last update of a repository is displayed (e.g. 3 seconds ago).

Sometimes it can take up to 3 hours to do an update for bigger repositories.
It would be very useful if users could see that the last update is xx minutes ago.
fields.summary: Display how long ago was the last update of a repository for non-administrator users

fields.description:
SVNKit appears to create a thread per repo request, which is undesirable for performance reasons. This problem is mentioned here:

http://svnkit.com/tracker/view.php?id=381

when a release contains the threadpool fix, upgrade to that version - Or since we are building SVNKit ourselves, we could consider using a trunk build?
fields.summary: SVNKit appears to create a thread per request

fields.description: When I push to the Git repository, Fisheye sends a new e-mail to the watchers of the project. Bu the mail content is not the latest commit as expected. It is the one before the latest commit. I have searched the tracker. But I could not find a similar issue.
fields.summary: Fisheye sends e-mails including not the latest Git commit but the commit before the last commit

fields.description: While browsing a source file the user would be able to click a function name, or a class, or a variable name, and then find all uses of that function/class/variable in the code across all repositories.
fields.summary: While browsing code, ability to see all uses of a function/class/variable

fields.description:
We have all Atlassian tools (JIRA, Confluence, Fisheye/Crucible, etc.) integrated into a Crowd SSO.  Fisheye/Crucible will not use the single sign on session.  For instance:

* Clear all cookies.
* Navigate to and login to JIRA.
* Navigate to Confluence, note that you're already logged in.
* Navigate to Fisheye, and you are required to login.

Fisheye has Crowd SSO enabled.  It has no problems authenticating against/importing users from Crowd, it simply won't use the single sign on session even though it is enabled.
fields.summary: FishEye/Crucible Crowd SSO not working

fields.description:
We have been running Crucible/Fisheye 2.1.2 for a while now, and continue to experience it crashing "out of swap space" memory errors.  We even changed the Java memory allocations to -Xms2048m -Xmx2048m -XX:MaxPermSize=256m but it did not help.  With no other solutions, we created a cron job to start fisheye whenever it crashes (usually 2-4 times per week).

We recently upgraded our dev server to version 2.4.3, and seeing that it now uses a mysql backend we were hopeful that this new version would eliminate the constant crashing.  Unfortunately, it did not.  And furthermore, it was unable to be restarted after the crash.  We got this error:
Problem starting FishEye and Crucible: com.cenqua.obfuscate.idblch0qi._FileCorruptedException: Bad file format opening InfinityDB file '/opt/crucible/fisheye-install/var/data/data0.bin' (bad initialBCell)
Even after I replaced that file with a backup, there were other repositories that could not be started due to a very similar error:
Failed to start repository activemq: com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.DbException: com.cenqua.obfuscate.idblch0qi._FileCorruptedException: Bad file format opening InfinityDB file '/opt/crucible/fisheye-install/var/cache/activemq/revcache/data.bin' (bad initialBCell)
It doesn't seem to make sense that fisheye is still using a file store database when it has a RDBMS such as mySQL at its disposal.

I rolled back to our 2.1.2 version.

I have attached a "support zip" from our 2.1.2 version, as well as logs from 2.4.3 when it crashed and did not restart cleanly.
fields.summary: Fisheye unable to be restarted after crash
Fisheye doesn't work with Crowd 2.1 integration Jar

fields.description:
If you go to {{Admin > Systems Settings > Sys-Info/Support}} and you do not have a SMTP Server set, the following message in a red box is displayed:
{code}You have not configured a SMTP Mail Server. Please do so in Admin > Server Settings > Mail Server{code}

This path is wrong. It should refer to {{Admin > Global Settings > Server}}.

Please let me know if you need further explanation.

Regards,
Felipe Kraemer
Atlassian Support
fields.summary: FishEye Sys-Info/Support page displays incorrect text when no SMTP is configured

fields.description:
Today we started with our, 5-year-old, CSV to connect Jira to fisheye. Unfortunally Fisheye will not index, although we have just 5 concurrent-users and the starter allows us to have 10. Our CVS contains a lot of information about the history and old-employees (and trainees) have committed a lot. Excluding the whole project or branch is not an option, because every file can be important ;-) 
We need a feature in Fisheye to start indexing from a specified date to our CVS.
fields.summary: Start indexing from specified date to CVS

fields.description:
It would be good to be able to Search for changesets in FishEye similar to how you would in Mercurial using Revsets. Some constraints include:
* ancestors(CSID)
* descendants(CSID)
* x - y: constraint x but not constraint y (might already be possible: x and not y ???)

This would probably require a change of focus from changesets to file revisions in EyeQL
fields.summary: Allow EyeQL to have DAG related constraints

fields.description:
To reproduce:

1. add p4 repo with an invalid username/password (e.g. "baduser")
2. leave the "show advanced settings" checkbox unchecked
3. hit "test connection"

Excpected:
 test connection log should show "-u baduser" on p4 command line

Actual:
 test connection log does not pass "-u baduser" on p4 command line

Workaround: 
 when adding a p4 repo, check the "show advanced settings" checkbox before testing connection or saving.

Diagnosis: 
 username & password fields incorrectly grouped in {{PerforceRepositoryDetails.AdvancedOptions}}
fields.summary: p4 add repo username/password ignored unless "show advanced settings" is checked.

fields.description:
For a reference of svn commit, we use a fisheye's diff url.
If a user has a fisheye account, he can see a diff view by his favorite diff mode.
But anonymous users can't store there user profile in crucible & fisheye.
And most of anonymous users want to view diff information by side by side mode.

For anonymous user, fisheye's default diff mode must be adjusted.
If system administrator can adjust a default diff mode, that's the best solution.
fields.summary: Fisheye's default diff mode cannot be changed from unified to side-by-side.

fields.description:
Our application links are configured to use an "internal" host name between jira and fisheye. In the Fisheye application links setup we have specified the "Display URL" setting as our "external" url which should be the base for all links generated out to jira, right?

*However links are still being rendered using the internal url*

This is a killer for us right now.
fields.summary: Links to Jira issues are using the application URL instead of the base URL

fields.description:
FishEye should support authentication for private remote mercurial repositories (esp. for http(s)).

btw: A vcs-mercurial component for the FisheEye project here in Jira is missing. ;-)
fields.summary: Support authentication for mercurial

fields.description:
Performance analysis of InfinityDb's cache locking indicates worse than expected degration as the number of concurrent read threads increase.

Work with InfinityDb to identify the cause and assist in its resolution. Adjust our access patterns if necessary in the meantime to avoid multiple fine grained database dips on a single request thread.
fields.summary: InfinityDb's global cache lock is inefficient

fields.description:
Example URL:

http://svnview.digium.com/svn/libss7/team/mattf/libss7-ss7cluster/isup.c?view=diff&rev=288&r1=287&r2=288

If you edit that URL and replace 'svnview.digium.com' with 'code.asterisk.org', you'll see what Fisheye displays in ViewVC compatibility mode. It properly moves to revision 288 of isup.c, but it apparently ignores the 'r1' and 'r2' parameters in the URL, instead it displays the entire content of the file as of revision 288. Using the 'from revision' drop-down list in the display to select revision 287 results in the proper diff being displayed.
fields.summary: Improve ViewVC URL compatibility for single-file revision diffs

fields.description:

Code - Issues Event (Stiefel, Jason)

Let me know if I should open an enhancement for the second part.

fields.description:
In FishEye, when you view an annotated view of a file, you cannot Ctrl+F (search) in your browser to find a string. You must first scroll to the bottom to engage the lazy loading of the rest of the content of the file.

It would be nice that if the keypress of Ctrl+F or F3 is detected, the full file is downloaded as if you had scrolled to the bottom.  We use the FishEye search to narrow in on a particular file, but often times the files are large and we want to jump to the match so that is why we'd use browser search.  And the links in the search results don't give you a line number, or a link directly to the match in the file (maybe thats an option).

I had assumed it wouldn't be ground breaking, considering all [new key shortcuts|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Using+Keyboard+Shortcuts+in+Crucible] you guys are adding to the Atlassian products across the board.  

Maybe another suggestion would be to make it a User Preference, allow people to specify if they want lazy loading of annotated files (obviously defaulted to yes).  And then if they have it on because they know they want to search, put one of those little banners you guys display at the top when you want to suggest something, i.e. "You could speed up your load times by enabling lazy loading."

Another reasonable compromise would be to give users an action that will force loading to complete rather than trying to jockey the browser UI to load all of the data.

Originally submitted as a support request (FSH-4740) but it was suggested to submit to public forum to see if it would garner other support.
fields.summary: Cannot Ctrl+F (search) on an annotated view of a file due to lazy loading

fields.description:
When viewing a FE repository settings page, several of the settings, such as Linkers now have a large cyan banner at the top:

"There are default linkers defined for all repositories. They will be used in addition to any you define here."

However, there are *no* linkers defined globally. The Defaults -> Linkers page confirms this:

"No linkers defined." 

Perhaps this is a documentation issue, or the text needs to say that global settings *could* override. Or there is a bug in detecting global settings and merging them in.

This happens with: Linkers, Permissions, Allow (Process), and Hidden Directories.
fields.summary: Repo indicates global settings will be applied, but there are no global settings defined

fields.description:
The branches/tags dropdown (which now works for git repos, thank you thank you thank you) has a severe limitation in the name of performance -- it can't show more than a few dozen branches/tags. Since you can type in (and search for) a tag or branch name, this isn't too bad, but it would be nice to have tabs that list the branches and tags as well, perhaps providing links that would send you back to the "Files" tab with the view set to the appropriate branch/tag.

(As an aside: Mixing branches and tags into one dropdown is really annoying -- they aren't the same thing, except in Subversion's seriously broken view of version control. :-P )

In case you're wondering, this is prompted by one of our repositories that has more than 400 branches and nearly 500 tags.
fields.summary: Branches/Tags dropdown is nice, but tabs would be useful, too.

fields.description:
With the recent acquisition of BitBucket, you may already be doing this -- this request is to add "pull request" tracking to FishEye.

This would enable better implementation of the "integrator workflow" (see http://progit.org/book/ch5-1.html)

Merge/Pull requests could show up as a task in your dashboard (with accompanying e-mail notification), alerting you that someone wants to you to merge (pull) changesets from one repo/branch to another. You then have a nice web-based conversation, tell the person to fix their whitespace damage (or critical bug they missed, etc) and perform a mini-code-review prior to a merge. You *could* do this with Crucible today, but a) not everyone has crucible, b) the UI is too involved, too many clicks.

"hg outgoing" shows you the changes in your repo/branch that are not in the other repo -- this just needs some nice UI to make it easier from the web interface.

Examples of pull/merge requests include the following
* https://github.com/rails/rails/pulls
* http://bitbucket.org/tortoisehg/stable/pull
* http://qt.gitorious.org/qt/qt/merge_requests
fields.summary: Add pull / merge requests to fisheye

fields.summary: Start Revision for Git and Hg

fields.description:
After upgrading from Fisheye 2.3.6 to Fisheye 2.4.0 the administration link redirected users to the IP address and port number for the proxy server that Fisheye was configured to use. The URL in the rendered HTML appears correct, but clicking on the link caused a redirect to the proxy server.

The link from config.xml with the proxy server information. This was the config.xml for Fisheye 2.3.6. Note, the IP address 10.10.10.10 below is a dummy address so that I don't expose our real server IP.

<http bind=":8060" proxy-port="8080" proxy-host="10.10.10.10" proxy-scheme="http"/>

In order to work around this issue I removed the proxy server information from config.xml and restarted Fisheye.

<http bind=":8060"/>

After making this change the administration link loads the correct pages.
fields.summary: Administration link redirects to proxy server address after upgrade from 2.3.6 to 2.4.0

Upon startup of FishEye 2.4 you may get this message: 

{quote}WARN: your default encoding (MacRoman) does not support unicode.
This is likely to cause problems if any of the filenames, branch names or tag names in one of your repositories contain unicode characters.
Update your locale settings or start with the -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 option to avoid these problems.{quote}

If its preferred to run with UTF-8 encoding we should probably set that by default.
fields.summary: Set -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 by default

fields.description:
If you add two repositories with a very similar name (only differentiated by a hyphen for example), Fisheye will only allow one of the repositories to start.

To reproduce:

1. Create a repository with a name like {{analysis-platform}}.
2. Create a second repository with a similar name, {{AnalysisPlatform}}.

Notice that in the repository list, the first repo will be indexing fine but the second repo will be Disabled and can't be enabled.  Furthermore, clicking on the second repository will go to the admin page of the first repository.

At this point the only workaround is to manually edit the {{config.xml}} file and change the name of the repository.  This will allow it to be enabled on startup, and then restarted.
fields.summary: Issues creating similarly named repositories

fields.description:
The starter license is great for 1 man shops and people that want to have source code tracking when using classic style source control systems like Subversion. With distributed source control systems development tends to have many repositories for just the same product or component of a product as well as per branch type such as tags, dev and main line. Because of this, the 5 repository limit seems to be a bit too harsh for users of DVCS while other repository systems don't need to worry about this restriction.
I've only worked with Subversion and Mercurial. Subversion can track individual file changes per revision while Mercurial makes it appear that the entire repository has changed each revision. This causes developers to make many repositories.

It would be helpful to significantly increase the repository restriction for DVCS or remove it altogether for the starter license.

A better explaination is here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2367453/recommended-mercurial-repository-folder-structure-for-an-svn-user
fields.summary: Relax the repository restriction for Fisheye starter license.

fields.description:
When you re-sync the FishEye userbase with LDAP, user attributes (e.g. email) are not updated in FE. 

To Reproduce: 

# Integrate with LDAP
# Check the email address of one of the users in FE.
# Change that users email address in LDAP
# Resync the userbase in FE
# Check the users email address again, it will be the old value. 

Our solution is to add a radio button set to the 'LDAP Authentication Settings' page, and to the 'JIRA or Crowd Authentication Settings' page.

It will have the title: "Display Name and Email Address Changes" and two radio buttons, the first reading "Update from LDAP on synchronisation and disable local editing." and the second reading "Update from LDAP only on creation of a new user, and allow local editing." (the captions will read "JIRA or Crowd" instead of LDAP on the 'JIRA or Crowd Authentication Settings' page)

On the 'Profile & Email' tab of the user Settings dialog the Display Name and Email Address fields will be disabled, and a message "Your user details are held externally, so your email address and display name cannot be edited in FishEye/Crucible." will be displayed when the first radio button is selected.
fields.summary: LDAP information is not refreshed on re-sync

fields.description:
Fisheye/Crucible does provide a handy web interface that allows you to easily integrate it with a Crowd server.  This is really handy but it only provides access to the basic Crowd properties:

* Application Name
* Password
* URL

In other applications you have access to the {{crowd.properties}} file, which provides more advanced fine-tuning of the Crowd integration (in particular {{session.validationinterval}}).

We should provide a mechanism via the Crowd integration UI in Fisheye/Crucible to set these parameters.
fields.summary: Document advanced Crowd client elements in Security Admin

fields.description:
There are a number of known issues with Mercurial support (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Mercurial+Known+Issues).  However, since CRUC-3279 has been closed due to alpha support being added to FishEye, there is no 'top-level' issue that can be watched to see when a version of FishEye is released with full Mercurial support.  This issue is intended to provide a watchable issue for that purpose.

We are considering purchasing FishEye & Crucible, but until non-alpha Mercurial support is included, this is not really an option.
fields.summary: Mercurial Support is only Alpha

fields.description:
Currently you can search in eyeQL for issues fixed with a Perforce JOB ID, but you can not display the results as part of the output.

Example:

{code}
select revisions from dir "/" where p4:jobid =~ "MYPROJECT"
 group by changeset 
{code}

This will find all the revisions that have a p4:jobid that include MYPROJECT in them.   However you can not return p4:jobid as a valid return item.

Returning the p4:job id would allow users to search changelists in Fisheye for the Perforce Job that fixed them, and allow easier integration with Jira for some tools.  Typically the Fix job for perforce is the Jira Issue ID (due to Jira integration with Perforce)
fields.summary: Fisheye: eyeQL return p4:jobids
